sentence: W. P. Carey Inc.WPC announced the acquisition of a class A office building in Jacksonville, FL for $17 million by one of its managed non-traded REITs - CPA: 18 - Global.
This property is triple-net leased to Acosta, Inc., a portfolio company of The Carlyle Group.
The move enables portfolio enhancement with a long-term triple-net lease asset with annual rent escalations averaging 3.26%.
The acquisition seems to be a strategic fit as it offers W. P. Carey's CPA: 18 - Global an opportunity to enhance its tenant roaster with a well-established company like Acosta.

Founded in 1927, this outsourced sales and marketing agency caters to consumer packaged goods companies and retailers in North America, and boasts a strong client base backed by reputed customers like The Clorox Company CLX , Coca-Cola, ConAgra Foods, Inc. CAG , and The Procter & Gamble Company PG .
Notably, the building was erected in 2001 as a build-to-suit for Acosta and continues to serve as its corporate headquarters to date.

It is located in one of the healthy office submarkets in Jacksonville where overall vacancy for Class A office was 3.6% at the end of the first quarter of 2015, comfortably lower than that of the overall Class A office market in Jacksonville.
Also, this acquisition will likely ensure a steady source of revenue for the company.
This is because the property is triple-net leased for 12 years and the lease incorporates annual rent escalations averaging 3.26%.
Hence, we believe that this is an acquisition in a thriving office submarket, which would add high long-term value to the company's portfolio.

Notably, W. P. Carey is a real estate investment trust ("REIT"), focusing on corporate sale-leaseback financing, build-to-suit construction financing and single-tenant net lease properties acquisition.

In addition to generating lease revenues from its owned real estate assets, the company earns fee revenue by acting as an advisor to a number of income-oriented, non-traded REITs through its investment management business.
